conclusion: To determine if the particle underwent variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph provided.
The graph shows the velocity of the particle as a function of time.
The x-axis represents time (t) in seconds.
The y-axis represents velocity (v) in meters per second (m/s).
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at v = 2 m/s.

premise: From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at v = 2 m/s.
conclusion: This indicates that the particle is moving with a constant velocity.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from v = 2 m/s to v = 0 m/s.

premise: From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from v = 2 m/s to v = 0 m/s.
conclusion: This indicates that the particle is decelerating.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from v = 0 m/s to v = -2 m/s.

conclusion: This indicates that the particle is accelerating in the negative direction.
Variable linear motion implies that the velocity is changing with time, but the acceleration is constant.

conclusion: The particle is undergoing variable linear motion in the first 3 seconds.
